papers.abstract: During interpersonal interactions, conversational moves can help people establish common ground —a shared frame of reference to support communication. Neurodiverse conversation dyads that include autistic and non-autistic members can experience challenges in creating and maintaining such a shared frame of reference due to differing communication and cognitive styles. We conducted a design study to understand conversational patterns among neurodiverse dyads and then used those patterns to co-design concepts for supporting the creation and maintenance of common ground by those conversation pairs. Our study involved two activities with participants: (1) a paired interview with autistic adults and a trusted conversation partner that used a novel swimlane visual elicitation activity, and (2) a remote design study during which the autistic participants designed a game intended to visualize and support neurodiverse conversation dynamics. We found that communication technology can scaffold neurodiverse dyads in locating common ground by supporting crucial individual and joint decision-making; clarification of language and emotions; and embodied sense-making of identity, relationships, and shared information. This project generated insights related to two distinct aspects of designing assistive Information and Communication Technology (ICT) to support autistic individuals: (1) the ability for visual elicitation activities to help autistic individuals recognize interaction patterns, gain a deeper understanding of other's perspectives, and imagine more desirable alternatives, and (2) the importance of recognizing and supporting multi-dimensional aspects of communication practices (i.e., social, emotional, sensory) in establishing and maintaining shared points of reference for neurodiverse conversation dyads.

papers.abstract: Digital data shape work practices as they travel through space, time, and social situations. In turn, workers shape the materiality of data through different data-oriented activities. In this paper, we draw on the theory of data journeys to develop and present a conceptual framework of four data-intensive activities: Producing, mobilising, processing, and re-purposing. Together, those activities capture entanglements of data transformations and data-intensive practices. We develop the framework through a qualitative study of digitisation in Environmental Assessment (EA) practice. EA practitioners reflect on their experiences working with digital environmental data through ten semi-structured and two interactive interviews. The paper offers two main contributions. First, we develop a data journey theoretical framework and show that it is useful as a unit of analysis for uncovering tensions in data-oriented activities. Second, we use these insights to outline a set of tensions for future design activities in the area of data work practices.

Together, those activities capture entanglements of data transformations and data-intensive practices.
events.Main Action: Developing and presenting a conceptual framework

Secondary Object: Four distinct types: producing, mobilising, processing, and repurposing

Context: Digital data shaping work practices across space, time, and social situations; Workers influencing data materiality through data-oriented activities
Purpose: Advancing understanding of data-intensive practices’ structural dynamics through framework development
Method: Using the theory of data journeys combined with qualitative analysis methods
Analysis: Focusing on four core activities captures essential data transformations and intensive practices
Challenge: Limitations including partial theoretical integration and practical challenges during application
Ethical: Concerns regarding dataset privacy and security risks associated with extensive data handling
Implications: Potential extensions toward integrated multi-context models addressing additional dimensions of data utilization

events.Text: We develop the framework through a qualitative study of digitisation in Environmental Assessment (EA) practice. EA practitioners reflect on their experiences working with digital environmental data through ten semi-structured and two interactive interviews.

Context: through a qualitative study of digitisation in Environmental Assessment (EA) practice.
Reflecting on their experiences working with digital environmental data through ten semi-structured and two interactive interviews.
Purpose: To create a comprehensive framework focused on digitization aspects relevant to environmental assessments
Method: Qualitative analysis methods applied to interview data collected from environmental assessment practitioners through ten semi-structured and two interactive interviews.
Results: Potential findings emerging from applying the framework validation against real-world scenarios.
Analysis: Insights gained from the study concerning how digitization impacts environmental assessments
Challenge: Ensuring consistency across varied responses from interviewees due to differing personal experiences and challenges in capturing nuanced feedback accurately.
Ethical: Issues relating to the practical application of digital tools in environmental assessments, particularly regarding accuracy and transparency in reporting.
Implications: Potential influence on future research directions and improvement of methodologies integrating technology in environmental assessments.
